description.narrative: EWA (Ethiopia WASH Alliance) is a consortium of NGOs and private organizations working on the enhancement of the well-being of people living in rural, pastoral and urban areas of the country. EWA’s partners are operating different districts in Afar and Oromia Regional State and Dire Dawa City Administration and National Level. Since 2011, EWA has created access to improved WASH services for more than 100,000 people. It works in rural and urban WASH along with improving access at institutions (schools and health centers). The result for sanitation has been reached applying Community Led Total Sanitation and Hygiene (CLTSH), Eco-san technology demonstration and hygiene and sanitation education. These made people aware of the benefits of sanitation and stimulated them to construct sanitation facilities at their household. In 2014 for example, as a result of CLTSH more than 8000 households built their own traditional latrines using their own materials. In our intervention areas results showed that there are increased menstrual hygienic behavior led to higher school enrolment of girls at schools. Combining sanitation and hygiene awareness with the provision of hardware facilities lead to the installment of separate toilet blocks for girls and boys. Also sanitation and hygiene education in the schools using School WASH clubs contributed to better management of the facilities. Realizing access and use of improved drinking water was stimulated through the establishment of Water Supply, Sanitation and Hygiene committees (WASHCOs). In these committees, representation of women is mandatory. More than 50% of the Water Committee members that received training mainly in operation and management of the schemes, financial management, preparing community WASH plans and bookkeeping were women. With regard to capacity building on using waste, efforts were undertaken to improve the solid waste management systems of small towns as well as turning WASH services into an economic opportunity for unemployed youths. EWA has raised awareness among decision makers and the public, and supported business development along the sanitation service and value chain in Dire Dawa, while linkages were made to similar experiences in Addis Ababa and other cities. As a result an increase in the cooperation of local governments with the private sector can be observed.

activity-date.narrative: Assessment of Rural water supply management system was conducted in the two target Districts (Sahshemene & Negele Arsi) from 04-14 December 2018. In this assessment, the water supply scheme status of each Kebeles in the two Districts assessed and a total of 10 Kebeles identified as potential for water supply construction to be done. Additionally, the functionality of each WASHCOs assessed and the need for our input was identified so that we will support and count the beneficiaries reached which finally counted as a leverage.

Planning workshop was conducted with the participation of 15 (all men) participants (Amref, IRC, BBBC & WI) from 29-30 November 2019. Plan of 2019: - Each partners discussed with other partners on their plan for 2019 by way of creating common understanding who needs what from whom. This session created a better understating where partners indicated the support they need from another partner in their plan for different activities. There was clear understanding amongst consortium partners in creating integration in the program implementation. Deliverables:- Each partner worked on their deliverables as per the comments given by Amref-NL and revised the deliverables. WI has come a kind new deliverables which they thought a better version of it. Leverage: - Each partners calculated the leverage for their organization that can be created from the WASH SDG Consortium program implementation and each partner has shared the filled excel sheet for their leverage calculation.

Project Launching workshop conducted at Hawasa on 6 November 2018. A total of 46 participants (4 women) from Oromia Regional Government Bureaus, Zonal sectors, relevant Woreda sectors, BBBC, IRC, WI and Amref participated in the workshop. The objectives of the workshop, project profile including detailed project activities and budget of each implementing partners presented and inputs were delivered from the participants. Finally, the launching was ended with the closing remark given from the Regional government representative.

Regarding WASH sector support, the Oromia Regional State Health Bureau requested us to give financial support and the Bureau covered 4 experts' per diem as the experts made Integrated Supportive Supervision.

Studies/mappings done
Including information on the topics of these studies/mappings in the comment column

comment.narrative: Detailed technical feasibility study on the rehabilitation of the water wells and a new well water supply scheme in the locality were conducted by technical team organized from Zonal water office and Amref in five targeted kebeles.

During the field WASH initial assessments water facilities functionality status, feasibility for rehabilitation, the existence of WASHCO on the WSS, and their functionality, and other issues were assessed. The assessment also focussed rural water supply inventory, health facility WASH facilities, School WASH facilities, and household hygiene and sanitation from the secondary data.

title.narrative: Number of dissemination meetings/activities organised where these studies/mappings have been presented

description.narrative: A dissemination meeting/activity is to present the findings of the study/mapping done. Information is included on who has been present or whom it has been presented to in the comment column.
